com.pi4j.component.adafruithat

Class AdafruitStepperMotor

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pi4j.component.ComponentBase
      • com.pi4j.component.motor.MotorBase
        • com.pi4j.component.motor.StepperMotorBase
          • com.pi4j.component.adafruithat.AdafruitStepperMotor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.pi4j.component.Component, com.pi4j.component.motor.Motor, com.pi4j.component.motor.StepperMotor

    public class AdafruitStepperMotor
extends com.pi4j.component.motor.StepperMotorBase
    This java class has been developed to command stepper motors wired to a "Adafruit DC and Stepper Motor HAT" developed for the Raspberry Pi

    See MotorHAT

    Up to two stepper motors can be controlled with the motor HAT. These motors are named "SM1" (corresponding to M1 and M2 pins) and "SM2" (M3 and M4 pins). Both DC and stepper motors can be wired to the same motor HAT.

    Use the AdafruitDCMotor class for commanding DC motors.

    An Adafruit Motor HAT can drive drive up to 4 DC or 2 Stepper motors with full PWM speed and direction control. The fully-dedicated PCA9685 PWM driver chip controls motor direction and speed. This chip handles all the motor and speed controls over I2C. Only two pins (SDA and SCL) are required to drive the multiple motors, and since it's I2C you can also connect any other I2C devices or other HATs to the same pins.

    This means up to 32 Adafruit Motor HATs can be stacked to control up to 128 DC motors or 64 stepper motors. The default I2C address for a HAT is 0x60 but can be modified with solder connections to alter the I2C Address. Motors are controlled with the TB6612 MOSFET driver with 1.2A per channel current capability (20ms long bursts of 3A peak).

    Author:
    Eric Eliason
    See Also:
    AdafruitDcMotor

      • setStepInterval

        public void setStepInterval(long milliSeconds,
                            boolean killFlag)
        This method is used to specify precise timing interval between between each motor step. The time interval applies only to step() and rotate() methods. A millisecond value of 0 indicates the stepping is to occur at the fastest possible rate.
        Parameters:
        milliSeconds - Time interval in milliseconds between each step. If 0 (default value) then stepping occurs at the fastest rate possible.
        killFlag - The killFlag instructs the step() and rotate() method to terminate if the milliSeconds between each step can not be achieved. true=terminate if time interval can not be achieved, false=keep stepping even if time interval can not be achieved.

      • setStepInterval

        public void setStepInterval(long milliSeconds)
        This method is used to specify precise timing interval between between each motor step. The time interval applies only to step() and rotate() methods. A millisecond value of 0 indicates the stepping is to occur at the fastest possible rate. If you want to specify that the Use the alternate overload method to specify that step() method is to terminate if the time interval can not be achieved.
        Specified by:
        setStepInterval in interface com.pi4j.component.motor.StepperMotor
        Overrides:
        setStepInterval in class com.pi4j.component.motor.StepperMotorBase
        Parameters:
        milliSeconds - Time interval in milliseconds between each step. If 0 (default value) then stepping occurs at the fastest rate possible.

      • setMode

        public void setMode(StepperMode stepperMode)
        Set the stepper mode. For information on the types of stepper modes see: https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-dc-and-stepper-motor-hat-for-raspberry-pi/overview Please note: the currentStep is reset to zero whenever there is a change in the stepperMode.
        Parameters:
        stepperMode - StepperMode.SINGLE_PHASE - Single phase is the simplest type of stepping and uses the least power. It uses a single coil to hold the motor in place alternating between the coils to make the step movement. StepperMode.DOUBLE_PHASE - Double Phase uses two coils on at once using twice the power but offering approximately 25% more holding power at the step. StepperMode.HALF_STEP - Mix of single and double phase alternately. This mode uses approximately twice the power but has twice as many steps per rotation. SteeperMode.MULTISTEP - This mode uses a mix of single and double stepping with PWM to slowly transition between steps. It is much slower than single step mode but has much higher precision and has 8 times the number of steps per rotation.

      • getCurrentStep

        public long getCurrentStep()
        Returns the currentStep number (number of steps the motor has incurred starting with 1 as the first step. Note that the currentStep is reset to zero whenever there is a change in the StepperMode. The currentStep can be negative if the motor is moving in the negative direction.
        Returns:
        currentStep

      • stop

        Stop all power and commanding to the stepper motor
        Specified by:

      • setStepsPerRevolution

        public void setStepsPerRevolution(int stepsPerRevolution)
        Specify the steps per revolution for this stepper motor. Many stepper motors have 200 steps per revolution. Please note this value must take into account the Stepper Mode employed. For SINGLE_PHASE or DOUBLE_PHASE mode use the physical motor steps. For HALF_STEP this value will be twice the number of physical motor steps. For MULTI_STEP this value will be 8 times the number of physical motor steps.
        Specified by:
        setStepsPerRevolution in interface com.pi4j.component.motor.StepperMotor
        Overrides:
        setStepsPerRevolution in class com.pi4j.component.motor.StepperMotorBase
